turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Skull cup.
turn.1: What was the historical and contemporary use of the Skull cup?
turn.2: In 19th century England, the poet Lord Byron used a skull his gardener had found at Newstead Abbey as a drinking vessel. "There had been found by the gardener, in digging, a skull that had probably belonged to some jolly monk or friar of the Abbey, about the time it was demonasteried.
turn.3: Why did he use it as a drinking vessel?
turn.4: Observing it to be of giant size, and in a perfect state of preservation, a strange fancy seized me of having it set and mounted as a drinking cup.
turn.5: What else did you find interesting about this article?
turn.6: I accordingly sent it to town, and it returned with a very high polish and of a mottled colour like tortoiseshell".
turn.8: Byron even wrote a darkly witty drinking poem as if inscribed upon it, “Lines Inscribed upon a Cup Formed from a Skull”.
turn.9: Is there anything else I should know?
turn.10: The cup, filled with claret, was passed around "in imitation of the Goths of old", among the Order of the Skull that Byron founded at Newstead, "whilst many a grim joke was cut at its expense", Byron recalled to Thomas Medwin.
